facts.text: Bishwanath Prasad, a workman of the appellant company, made a written complaint to the officer in charge of Nirsa Police station on September 19, 1960, alleging harassment by management and that an Assistant Manager, Labour Welfare Officer and others broke open the lock of worker Kashi Nath Singh's room and threw away his belongings while he was on duty.
After enquiry, the officer in charge of Nirsa police station submitted a final report on November 19, 1960, stating that complainant Bishwanath Prasad had deliberately brought a false complaint.
Sub-Divisional Officer dismissed the complaint on January 12, 1961, acting on the final police report.

Management served Bishwanath Prasad with a charge sheet on January 23, 1961, to show cause why disciplinary action should not be taken for misconduct in making serious defamatory allegations against officers.
Bishwanath Prasad's explanation to charge sheet: he made the police report after receiving complaint from Kashi Nath Singh to pacify excited workers, not to undermine prestige of officers.
Enquiry fixed for January 30, 1961; respondent failed to attend and requested open enquiry with Labour Department representatives.
Enquiry officer submitted report; management dismissed respondent from service effective from suspension date, January 23, 1961.
Trouble in factory on January 10, 1961, due to inter-Union rivalry; one group assaulted another; company dismissed 10 workmen on January 28, 1961.
Government of Bihar referred industrial dispute to Labour Court, Ranchi on March 28, 1961, regarding dismissal of 11 workmen including Bishwanath Prasad.
Labour Court awarded on February 23, 1962, upholding dismissals, finding no want of good faith, victimisation, unfair practice, basic error, or perverse findings per Indian Iron and Steel principles.
Labour Court found no evidence of pendency of conciliation proceedings; carbon copies of letters to Labour Officer not proven delivered.
Respondent filed petition under Arts. 226/227 before Patna High Court challenging Labour Court award.
Patna High Court on October 12, 1965, set aside Labour Court award and remitted matter back for fresh award, directing opportunity to prove conciliation pendency and S.33 violation.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Patna High Court properly appreciated the scope of S.33(2)(b) of the Industrial Disputes Act and correctly remitted the matter back to Labour Court on ground of possible contravention of S.33.
Whether pendency of conciliation proceedings affects the merits of dismissal, and if violation of S.33 renders departmental enquiry unavailable and requires reinstatement.
Whether Labour Court correctly applied principles from Indian Iron and Steel Co. case in upholding dismissal.

petitioner_arguments.text: Dismissal was after proper enquiry; respondent admitted lodging false police complaint defaming officers, subversive of discipline.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Principles in Indian Iron and Steel Co. Ltd. v. Their Workmen

petitioner_arguments.text: No evidence of conciliation pendency; even if violation of S.33, Labour Court must still examine merits under S.10 reference.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Sections 33, 33A, 10 of Industrial Disputes Act; Punjab National Bank Ltd. v. Its Workmen

respondent_arguments.text: Dismissal violated S.33 due to pendency of conciliation proceedings; enquiry held by employer of no avail; entitled to reinstatement.
Enquiry officer acted mala fide and violated natural justice; Labour Court ignored conciliation letters.

court_reasoning.text: High Court failed to appreciate true scope of S.33(2)(b); pendency of conciliation does not affect merits; Labour Court must still examine if dismissal justified per Indian Iron principles even if S.33 violated.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Violation of S.33 does not automatically invalidate dismissal or bar enquiry; tribunal adjudicates merits as under S.10.

court_reasoning.text: No allegation of S.33A proceedings; assuming conciliation pendency before Labour Officer, S.33A not attracted; employer can justify on merits.
court_reasoning.key_observation: S.33 removes ban but does not validate order per se; dispute under S.10 requires full merits enquiry.

court_reasoning.text: Labour Court correctly found no good faith want, victimisation, unfair practice, basic error or perverse finding; respondent's false complaint admitted and merited dismissal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Respondent admitted lodging complaint; falsity not denied; action subversive of discipline.

holdings.text: High Court's order remitting matter back to Labour Court not justified; Labour Court award upheld as dismissal proper.
Even if S.33 contravened, tribunal must consider merits of dismissal; no automatic reinstatement.

precedents_cited.case_name: Indian Iron and Steel Co. Ltd. v. Their Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Principles for tribunal interference in misconduct dismissals: no interference unless want of good faith, victimisation, unfair practice, basic error, or perverse finding.

precedents_cited.case_name: Punjab National Bank Ltd. v. Its Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Scope of Ss.10, 33, 33A; S.33 violation does not end matter; tribunal examines merits under S.10 reference.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rodrick v. Karam Chand Thapar Bros.
precedents_cited.relevance: Under S.33A, if S.33 contravened, employer can still justify dismissal on merits; does not help respondent here.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Regulates dismissal during pendency of conciliation/proceedings; violation does not preclude merits adjudication by tribunal.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for High Court petition challenging Labour Court award.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside Patna High Court order remitting matter to Labour Court, and upheld Labour Court's award maintaining dismissal of respondent Bishwanath Prasad and other workmen.
outcome.relief_granted: Appeal allowed; High Court order quashed.

key_quotes.text: In case of dismissal on misconduct, the Tribunal does not, however, act as a Court of appeal and substitute its own judgment for that of the management.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core principle limiting tribunal interference from Indian Iron case.

key_quotes.text: These sections do not lend themselves to the construction that as soon as the Labour Court finds that there has been a violation of S.33 it should award reinstatement.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies no automatic reinstatement for S.33 violation.

key_quotes.text: The Tribunal would have also to consider whether the impugned orders of dismissal are otherwise justified.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Emphasizes merits enquiry even post S.33 violation.
